March 1917.SECRET.WAR CABINET, 89.Minutes of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10, downing Street, on Tuesday,March 6, 1917, at 12*30 p.m.The Right Hon. the Earl curzon of kedleston, KG., G.C.S.L, G.C.I.E.The Right Hon. the Viscount Milner,G.C.B., G.C.M.G.Present:The Prime Minister (in the Chair).The Right Hon. A. Henderson, M.P.The Right Hon. A. Bonar Law, M.P.The following were also present :-The Right Hon. A. J. Balfour, O.M., M.P.,Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs.The Right Hon. the Earl of Derby, K.G.,G.C.V.O., C.B., Secretary of State forWar.The Right Hon. Sir E. Carson, K.C.,M.P., First Lord of the Admiralty.General Sir W. R. Robertson, G.C.B.,K.C.V.O., D.S.O., Chief of the ImperialGeneral Staff.Lieutenant-Colonel Sir M. P. A. Hankey, K.C.B., Secretary.The Western Front. THE Chief of the Imperial General Staff laid before the WarCabinet Sir Douglas Haig's views, as contained in his precis of the2nd instant, reviewing the present situation on the Western Front,with special reference to the German withdrawal north of the somme, and, in particular, his opinion that, in view of the situation,he should for the present retain sufficient reserves in his own handsto meet any possible action on the enemy's part.The War Cabinet decided that No action on their part was necessary pending the result of thediscussion which is to take place between Field-marshal sir Douglas Haig and General Nivelle, when the formershould, if necessary, report to the War Cabinet for instructions in accordance with the procedure laid downin paragraph 2 (3) of the Calais Agreement of the27th February, 1917 (War Cabinet, 82, Appendix III).(Initialled) D.
